APT29 Targeting Government Agencies

By Security Research Team | January 15, 2024

Executive Summary

This report details a sophisticated cyber espionage campaign attributed to APT29 (also known as Cozy Bear) targeting government agencies in Europe and North America during Q4 2023. The campaign demonstrates advanced tradecraft and multiple stages of intrusion.

Initial Access

The attackers initiated the campaign through spearphishing emails containing malicious PDF attachments. These emails were carefully crafted to appear as legitimate diplomatic communications, leveraging current geopolitical events to increase their success rate.

Upon opening the PDF attachment, a macro-enabled document was extracted and executed, establishing the initial foothold. The malicious macro utilized obfuscated PowerShell commands to download the next-stage payload from a compromised legitimate website.

Execution and Persistence

The PowerShell script executed several commands to establish persistence. First, it created a scheduled task that would run daily at system startup, ensuring the malware maintained access even after system reboots.

Additionally, the attackers modified Windows registry keys to enable further execution capabilities and disable certain security features. The malware also injected code into legitimate Windows processes to avoid detection.

Credential Harvesting

Once established, the attackers deployed credential dumping tools to extract credentials from LSASS memory. They also utilized keylogging capabilities to capture passwords entered by users during normal operations.

The stolen credentials were then used to access additional systems within the network using legitimate authentication mechanisms, making the lateral movement difficult to distinguish from normal administrative activity.

Lateral Movement

Using the harvested credentials, APT29 moved laterally across the network using Windows Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) and Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI). This allowed them to access high-value targets including file servers and domain controllers.

Data Collection and Exfiltration

The attackers collected sensitive documents from compromised systems, focusing on classified materials and strategic planning documents. Files were compressed into encrypted archives before exfiltration.

Data exfiltration occurred through HTTPS connections to attacker-controlled infrastructure, disguised as normal web traffic. The attackers used cloud storage services as an additional exfiltration channel, uploading stolen data to compromised cloud accounts.

Recommendations

  • Implement strict email filtering and disable macros by default
  • Deploy endpoint detection and response (EDR) solutions
  • Enable PowerShell logging and monitor for suspicious commands
  • Implement multi-factor authentication across all systems
  • Regular security awareness training for employees
